body:
**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

likely not a bug, you should be using `load_only(alias.age)`.  please confirm.

**malthe ([@malthe](https://github.com/malthe)) wrote:**

Actually I failed to reproduce the actual problem in this test case.

But there is an issue which is that the alias results in a subselect that lists all the columns in the mapper even though they're not part of the column selection:

```sql
select a, b from (select a, b, c from foo join bar on ...)
```
Note how ``c`` is not in the result, but it's still being listed in the subselect.

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

it's time to provide a real test case :).   Here's a start:


```
from sqlalchemy import *
from sqlalchemy.orm import *
from sqlalchemy.ext.declarative import declarative_base

Base = declarative_base()

class A(Base):
    __tablename__ = 'a'
    id = Column(Integer, primary_key=True)


e = create_engine("sqlite://", echo=True)
Base.metadata.create_all(e)

s = Session(e)

```

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

oh, does your test case show this?  I can look there.

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

hm, I see a fork of SQLAlchemy there. just give me a quick .py script, thanks.

**malthe ([@malthe](https://github.com/malthe)) wrote:**

yeah here's the diff: https://github.com/malthe/sqlalchemy/commit/dcd43de436bffaf91cce6bd2e7256dcdbb184896

I thought I'd write a test case against the code base.

I run the test via:
```bash
./sqla_nose.py -sxv -w orm/test_deferred.py
```

But I can try and isolate to a simple .py file.

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

OK, those tests can be helpful when I put the fix in but I need to understand the issue first (I'm fixing something else right now).

**malthe ([@malthe](https://github.com/malthe)) wrote:**

Here's a snippet that *does* demonstrate the issue:
```python
from sqlalchemy import *
from sqlalchemy.orm import *
from sqlalchemy.ext.declarative import declarative_base

Base = declarative_base()

class A(Base):
    __tablename__ = 'a'

    id = Column(Integer, primary_key=True)
    a_name = Column(String)


class B(A):
    __tablename__ = 'b'

    id = Column(Integer, ForeignKey("a.id"), primary_key=True)
    b_name = Column(String)


class C(Base):
    __tablename__ = 'c'

    id = Column(Integer, primary_key=True)
    c_name = Column(String)
    b_id = Column("b_id", Integer, ForeignKey("b.id"))

    b = relationship(B)

e = create_engine("sqlite://", echo=True)
Base.metadata.create_all(e)

s = Session(e)

b = B(id=1, a_name="foo", b_name="bar")
s.add(b)

c = C(id=1, b_id=b.id, c_name="boo")
s.add(c)

s.flush()

print s.query(C).join(B).options(
    contains_eager(C.b).load_only("id")
)
```
Note how ``a.a_name`` is included, but ``b.b_name`` is correctly excluded.

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

ok, so is this the bug?


```
from sqlalchemy import *
from sqlalchemy.orm import *
from sqlalchemy.ext.declarative import declarative_base

Base = declarative_base()

class A(Base):
    __tablename__ = 'a'

    id = Column(Integer, primary_key=True)
    a_name = Column(String)

class B(A):
    __tablename__ = 'b'

    id = Column(Integer, ForeignKey("a.id"), primary_key=True)
    b_name = Column(String)


s = Session()

print s.query(B).options(load_only(B.id))

```

it isn't looking at the superclass.  can we rename this issue then?  This is all I'm looking at so far.


```
SELECT b.id AS b_id, a.id AS a_id, a.a_name AS a_a_name 
FROM a JOIN b ON a.id = b.id
```

**malthe ([@malthe](https://github.com/malthe)) wrote:**

I think that's the bug. Let me rename the issue.

**Changes by malthe ([@malthe](https://github.com/malthe)):**

* changed **title** from "Load options ignore inherited classes with alias" to "Load options aren't looking at the superclass"

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

- The "wildcard" loader options, in particular the one set up by
the :func:`.orm.load_only` option to cover all attributes not
explicitly mentioned, now takes into account the superclasses
of a given entity, if that entity is mapped with inheritance mapping,
so that attribute names within the superclasses are also omitted
from the load.  Additionally, the polymorphic discriminator column
is unconditionally included in the list, just in the same way that
primary key columns are, so that even with load_only() set up,
polymorphic loading of subtypes continues to function correctly.
fixes #3287


→ b63aae2c232f

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

- The "wildcard" loader options, in particular the one set up by
the :func:`.orm.load_only` option to cover all attributes not
explicitly mentioned, now takes into account the superclasses
of a given entity, if that entity is mapped with inheritance mapping,
so that attribute names within the superclasses are also omitted
from the load.  Additionally, the polymorphic discriminator column
is unconditionally included in the list, just in the same way that
primary key columns are, so that even with load_only() set up,
polymorphic loading of subtypes continues to function correctly.
fixes #3287

(cherry picked from commit b63aae2c232f980a47aa2a635c35dfa45390f451)

Conflicts:
	lib/sqlalchemy/orm/mapper.py


→ 11383dae8d14

**Changes by Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)):**

* changed **status** to closed

issue.title: Load.load_only based on subclass doesn't get recognized

labels.name: loader options
labels.description: ORM options like joinedload(), load_only(), these are complicated and have a lot of issues

issue.body:
**Migrated issue, originally created by Dmytro Starosud ([@dima-starosud](https://github.com/dima-starosud))**

This is using SQLAlchemy==1.2.14.
Please consider following code snippet:

```
from sqlalchemy import Column, Integer, String, create_engine
from sqlalchemy.ext.declarative import declarative_base
from sqlalchemy.orm import Load, Query
from sqlalchemy.pool import NullPool

engine = create_engine('postgresql://***', poolclass=NullPool)
connection = engine.connect()
connection.begin_nested()

Base = declarative_base()


class MyEntity(Base):
    __tablename__ = 'my_entity'

    id = Column(Integer, primary_key=True)

    a = Column(String, nullable=False)
    b = Column(String, nullable=False)
    kind = Column(String, nullable=False)

    __mapper_args__ = {'polymorphic_on': kind}


Base.metadata.create_all(connection)


class MyChild(MyEntity):
    __mapper_args__ = {'polymorphic_identity': 'child_1'}


print(MyEntity)
print(Query(MyEntity).options(Load(MyEntity).load_only('a')))
print(MyChild)
print(Query(MyChild).options(Load(MyChild).load_only('a')))
```

It produces following output:


```
<class '__main__.MyEntity'>
SELECT my_entity.id AS my_entity_id, my_entity.a AS my_entity_a, my_entity.kind AS my_entity_kind
FROM my_entity
<class '__main__.MyChild'>
SELECT my_entity.id AS my_entity_id, my_entity.a AS my_entity_a, my_entity.b AS my_entity_b, my_entity.kind AS my_entity_kind
FROM my_entity
WHERE my_entity.kind IN (:kind_1)
```

Please assist. Did I misread documentation? Note unbound `load_only('a')` works well.

issue.title: Using load_only on joinedload for polymorphic relation loads more columns

labels.name: loader options
labels.description: ORM options like joinedload(), load_only(), these are complicated and have a lot of issues

labels.name: inheritance
labels.description: issues to do wtih ORM inheritance, a particularly tricky area

issue.body:
This is using sqlalchemy==1.2.16

Following snippet produces SQL that loads more attributes (other_attribute) than was asked for:

```
from sqlalchemy import Column, ForeignKey, Integer, Unicode, create_engine
from sqlalchemy.ext.declarative import declarative_base
from sqlalchemy.orm import Query, relationship, joinedload
from sqlalchemy.pool import NullPool

engine = create_engine(
    'mysql://**',
    poolclass=NullPool
)

connection = engine.connect()
connection.begin()

Base = declarative_base()


class Context(Base):
    __tablename__ = 'context'
    id = Column(Integer, primary_key=True)
    context_type = Column(Unicode(256), nullable=False)

    parent = relationship('Context')

    parent_id = Column(
        Integer, ForeignKey(
            'context.id'
        ), nullable=True
    )
    __mapper_args__ = {'polymorphic_on': context_type}


class Task(Context):
    __tablename__ = 'task'
    __mapper_args__ = {'polymorphic_identity': 'child1'}
    id = Column(
        Integer,
        ForeignKey('context.id'),
        primary_key=True
    )


class Project(Context):
    __tablename__ = 'project'

    id = Column(
        Integer,
        ForeignKey('context.id'),
        primary_key=True
    )

    full_name = Column(Unicode(256))

    other_attribute = Column(Unicode(256))


Base.metadata.create_all(connection)

query = Query(Task).options(
    joinedload(Task.parent.of_type(Project)).load_only('full_name')
)

print(query)
```

The following query is produced:

`
SELECT task.id AS task_id, context.id AS context_id, context.context_type AS context_context_type, context.parent_id AS context_parent_id, anon_1.context_id AS anon_1_context_id, anon_1.context_context_type AS anon_1_context_context_type, anon_1.project_id AS anon_1_project_id, anon_1.project_full_name AS anon_1_project_full_name, anon_1.project_other_attribute AS anon_1_project_other_attribute
FROM context JOIN task ON context.id = task.id LEFT OUTER JOIN (SELECT context.id AS context_id, context.context_type AS context_context_type, context.parent_id AS context_parent_id, project.id AS project_id, project.full_name AS project_full_name, project.other_attribute AS project_other_attribute
FROM context LEFT OUTER JOIN project ON context.id = project.id) AS anon_1 ON context.id = anon_1.context_parent_id
`

Where as sqlalchemy==1.1.4 gave, which omits other_attribute in the outer select:

`
SELECT task.id AS task_id, context.id AS context_id, context.context_type AS context_context_type, context.parent_id AS context_parent_id, anon_1.context_id AS anon_1_context_id, anon_1.context_context_type AS anon_1_context_context_type, anon_1.project_id AS anon_1_project_id, anon_1.project_full_name AS anon_1_project_full_name
FROM context JOIN task ON context.id = task.id LEFT OUTER JOIN (SELECT context.id AS context_id, context.context_type AS context_context_type, context.parent_id AS context_parent_id, project.id AS project_id, project.full_name AS project_full_name, project.other_attribute AS project_other_attribute
FROM context LEFT OUTER JOIN project ON context.id = project.id) AS anon_1 ON context.id = anon_1.context_parent_id
`

I've been trying with more explicit alias and with_polymorphic approaches, but it gives same result.
